title: Obama urges Palestinians to new peace talks
content:
Obama urged direct negotiations during an appearance with Mahmoud Abbas . Obama urges Palestinians on peace
RAMALLAH , West Bank — President Barack Obama on Thursday presented himself as a willing messenger to help peace talks between Israeli and Palestinian leaders — but reiterated that they ’ re the ones who need to take the lead .
And , he said in a joint appearance with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas here , those talks need to come without preconditions and Israelis and Palestinians need to “ push through ” obstacles to peace .
“ If the expectation is , is that we can only have direct negotiations when everything is settled ahead of time , then there ’ s no point for negotiations , ” Obama said . “ So I think it ’ s important for us to work through this process , even if there are irritants on both sides . ”
And in a possible signal to Abbas that he needs to be more flexible , Obama cited the “ complex ” politics in Israel as part of the reason finding a resolution to the conflict is difficult .
Obama — on his first trip to Israel and the Palestinian territories as president — outlined what he sees as the American role going forward : to help “ build confidence , rebuild a sense of trust . ”
Obama and Abbas met for more than an hour before the short press conference , following a morning launch of rockets from the Hamas-controlled Gaza , two of which landed in southern Israel . That and the issue of Israeli settlements in the West Bank loomed over the meeting between the two leaders as Obama urged the end to violence and Abbas repeatedly called for an immediate end to “ illegal ” settlements .
Obama said he ’ d discussed the issue at length when he met with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday , the first day of his trip , and that America opposes settlement-building . But the president kept his distance from Abbas ’ s position that ending settlements should be a precondition for peace talks — and was more restrained on the topic than he has been previously , when in 2009 he said that America “ does not accept the legitimacy of continued Israeli settlements , ” and said that such construction must stop .
“ I ’ ve been clear with Prime Minister Netanyahu and other Israeli leadership that it has been the United States policy , not just for my administration but for all proceeding administrations , that we do not consider continued settlement activity to be constructive , to be appropriate , to be something that can advance the cause of peace , ” Obama said in Ramallah . “ So I don ’ t think there ’ s any confusion in terms of what our position is . ”
Obama also spoke to Israel ’ s security concerns , referencing those fears on several occasions and pointing to the Thursday morning attack as an example .
